root_causes: Per-cell validation incorrectly treats missing numeric cells as errors even though question is NotRequired=true. The script uses (miss(v) or ~range(v,0,9999)) which flags missing values.
Per-cell range check should only apply when a value is present (i.e., not missing).
instructions: Change the per-cell check to only flag out-of-range values when the cell is non-missing. Replace the condition 'if flt_B5dx1 = 1 and (miss(v) or ~range(v,0,9999))' with 'if flt_B5dx1 = 1 and (not(miss(v)) and ~range(v,0,9999))'.

Do not unconditionally flag missing numeric cells. Rely on the DK-interplay checks already present: require at least one numeric when B5dDKx1 = 0 or missing, and require all numeric cells missing when B5dDKx1 = 1.
Ensure ordering of checks does not produce false positives: run the per-cell range-only checks first, then the DK domain/exclusivity and presence checks (which you already have).

Do not unconditionally flag missing numeric cells. Use the DK-interplay checks to enforce presence/absence of numeric data depending on B5dDKx2 (already implemented).
Ensure per-cell range checks are executed before DK-exclusive presence checks to avoid false positives.

root_causes: Script references variable B3cDKx1 but expected variable is B3cDKx1_99 (multi-select indicator for answer code 99).
instructions: Use the correct indicator variable name for the multi-select 'Other' code. Replace B3cDKx1 with B3cDKx1_99 in all statements.
Specifically, update the selection and listing to: sel if miss(B3cDKx1_99) or ~range(B3cDKx1_99,99,99). list respid, B3cDKx1_99.
Confirm that the dataset contains the B3cDKx1_99 variable (multi-coded indicator) before running the script.

root_causes: Script references the main multi variable B3cDKx1 instead of the specific coded sub-variable B3cDKx1_99 specified in the expected logic.
Selection condition is inverted: the script uses ~any(B3cDKx1,99) which selects cases that did NOT pick code 99, whereas expected validation should focus on handling the 99 (Other) code.
No check for the required open-text follow-up when code 99 (Other) is selected (AutoCheckOther = true).
instructions: Reference the specific sub-variable for the 'Other' code. Replace occurrences of B3cDKx1 with B3cDKx1_99 in the validation logic.

Change the selection condition so it identifies respondents who selected code 99. For example: sel if any(B3cDKx1_99,99). If you also want to include overall missing responses, use: sel if miss(B3cDKx1) or any(B3cDKx1_99,99).

Add a follow-up check to ensure that when 99 is selected the corresponding open-text variable is non-missing (name will depend on your dataset, e.g. B3cDKx1_99_TEXT). Example: sel if any(B3cDKx1_99,99) and miss(B3cDKx1_99_TEXT).
Ensure the final list command outputs the correct variables (respid plus the sub-variable and any follow-up text field) for review.

root_causes: Script references the main multi variable B3cDKx2 instead of the specific coded sub-variable B3cDKx2_99 specified in the expected logic.
Selection condition is inverted: uses ~any(B3cDKx2,99), which selects respondents who did NOT choose 99 instead of focusing on those who did.
Missing validation for the required open-text response when 99 (Other) is selected (AutoCheckOther = true).
instructions: Use the sub-variable B3cDKx2_99 in the validation logic instead of B3cDKx2.

Modify the sel if condition to flag respondents who selected code 99. For example: sel if any(B3cDKx2_99,99). To also capture cases where the whole question is missing, use: sel if miss(B3cDKx2) or any(B3cDKx2_99,99).
Add a check to ensure the corresponding open-text field (e.g. B3cDKx2_99_TEXT or the actual variable name) is not missing when 99 is selected: sel if any(B3cDKx2_99,99) and miss(B3cDKx2_99_TEXT).
Return respid and the relevant sub-variable and text field in the list output.

root_causes: Script references B3cDKx3 rather than the expected sub-variable B3cDKx3_99.
Condition uses ~any(B3cDKx3,99) (inverted), selecting respondents who did NOT pick 99 rather than those who did.
No handling to enforce/validate the open-text response when AutoCheckOther (99) is selected.
instructions: Replace references to B3cDKx3 with the specific sub-variable B3cDKx3_99.
Adjust the selection logic to identify cases with code 99: sel if any(B3cDKx3_99,99). If also intended to capture missing responses, use: sel if miss(B3cDKx3) or any(B3cDKx3_99,99).
Add an explicit check that when 99 is selected the corresponding 'other' text field is non-missing (e.g. sel if any(B3cDKx3_99,99) and miss(B3cDKx3_99_TEXT)).
Ensure the list statement includes respid, B3cDKx3_99 and the open-text field.

root_causes: Script uses B3cDKx4 instead of the expected sub-variable B3cDKx4_99.
The logic is inverted (~any(B3cDKx4,99)), so it selects respondents who did not choose 99 rather than those who did.
Missing validation for the associated open-text field when 99 is selected (AutoCheckOther = true).
instructions: Reference B3cDKx4_99 (the specific coded 'Other' sub-variable) in the sel if condition instead of B3cDKx4.

Change the condition to flag respondents who selected code 99, for example: sel if any(B3cDKx4_99,99). To also include missing overall responses if required: sel if miss(B3cDKx4) or any(B3cDKx4_99,99).
Add a follow-up validation that the open-text response tied to 99 is present when 99 is selected (e.g. sel if any(B3cDKx4_99,99) and miss(B3cDKx4_99_TEXT)).
Include respid, the sub-variable, and the open-text field in the list output for review.
